column4: I got this output from fdisk -l on a live CD: http://pastebin.com/3eVHn21e which is obviously wrong. ikonia said that I had to redo all partitions in order to get my Ubuntu installing. Any other solution you know of?

the difference between the partitions on the RAID and the ones actually mounted, Ubuntu detects some partitions on sda which is part of a RAID setup and did not use the partitions on md0 which also are detected incorrectly
perhaps check cfdisk output and what parted/gparted  says about it.  'fdisk' is getting a little out dated with a lot of these new setups and complex drive layouts.
okay, thanks, I'll try that. I'm worried that neither 10.10 nor 11.04 is able to detect the correct layout especially as everything is working fine in Windows
ive given up on using complex raid and other fancy layouts. :) I just do one HD per OS these days.
:D I used to have the setup this way on my old computer, here's the layout as it should be seen in Windows: http://tinypic.com/view.php?pic=2qv5url&s=7
is there a tutorial for installing from USB?
use a tool to put iso on the usb flash.. and boot it.. install..
/exec  - check the irssi docs for mor einfo  on it.
nsf server may be set to only allow access from a  the same network range as its on.  Vbox  can set up its own private network. check the ip#'s
uh well okay, thanks. I will have to look if I have any options to configure on my NAS
you can set vbox to  appear on the local lan as if it was a real physical machine.
zykotick9: you, I'll look into it :)
i would guess.. nfs security settings. :)
might be but as the options I can change on the NAS are somewhat limited, I dunno :)
